source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion-resistant to steam at temperatures as high as 450°C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: low-neutron-capture cross section. Calculations show that its cross section is 4 percent lower than that of Zircaloy-2

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion tests were done in organic coolant to determine the behavior of Ozhennite 0.5. These tests, of up to 12,000-h duration

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: Water concentrations in the coolant were maintained between 80 and 150 ppm, the dissolved hydrogen concentration at 60 to 150 cm³/kg, and chlorine at less than 0.5 ppm

conditions.atmosphere: water 80-150 ppm, hydrogen 60-150 cm³/kg, chlorine <0.5 ppm

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: long-term, steady-state hydriding rates determined for Ozhennite 0.5 in these tests, at temperatures over the range 350 to 490°C

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: hydriding rate of Ozhennite O.5 is almost one third that of 2.5Nb zirconium

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1
evidence_span: corrosion rate is also about one third that of the other alloys; for example, at 400°C, corrosion rates of 0.10 and 0.27 mg/dm²/day were measured for Ozhennite 0.5 and the zirconium-niobium alloy, respectively

evidence_span: A pressure tube for such a reactor might typically be 3.25 in. in internal diameter, with a wall thickness of 0.14 in., and operate with organic coolant at a temperature of 400°C

evidence_span: this would be reached with Ozhennite 0.5 in 17 yr. Comparable times for 2.5Nb zirconium and Zircaloy-4 would be 7 and 4 yr, respectively

source_id: STP458-EB-Zirconium in the Nuclear Industry_1st Volume_023_chunk1

evidence_span: A second application of Ozhennite 0.5 in organic-cooled reactors would be as fuel cladding. Again, the prime requirement is that of hydriding resistance, although adequate strength and ductility are important.
